Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Jamie, an old friend I hadn’t seen in months. I answered, expecting a quick hello, but Jamie’s voice trembled, “My car broke down. I’m stuck on Maple Road. Can you help?” I glanced at the clock—my shift had just started, and my supervisor had reminded us that every call counted toward our quota. As a telemarketer, I was expected to stay glued to my headset, ready to handle any customer objection with the perfect line from my script. Missing even a few calls could mean a warning.

But Jamie sounded desperate, and as an acquaintance, I knew I should offer help, maybe even drive out to pick them up. My mind raced, torn between the pressure to perform at work and the urge to be there for someone in need. I could already hear my supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me of the importance of every minute. At the same time, I pictured Jamie alone on that quiet road, waiting for someone to care enough to show up. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides.
